header.title: Discordia! A Little Game about a Lot of Chaos
header.category: Role-Playing Game, Esoteric Philosophy, Chaos Magic

central_thesis: The core thesis of 'Discordia!' posits that Chaos is the natural and fundamental condition of Reality, and that 'Everything is True – Even False Things'. This epistemological anarchy forms the basis for a role-playing game wherein 'Discordian Double Agents' strategically manipulate 'Catma' (absolute non-belief) and 'Dogma' (authoritative belief structures of various conspiracies) to navigate and subvert perceived order, thereby embodying a practical application of Discordian philosophy within a game system that mirrors Chaos Magical principles.

structure_content.chapter_title: PART NONE: THE CIRCULATION OF THE COSMOS IS RESTRICTED AS IT UNFOLDS
structure_content.summary: This section introduces the foundational Discordian philosophy, emphasizing that reality is inherently chaotic and order is an imposed illusion. It recounts the myth of 'The Snub' (Eris's exclusion from a divine party, leading to the Golden Apple of Discord) as the origin of operative chaos. The chapter underscores the principle that 'anything might be true,' including contradictory truths, setting the stage for reality manipulation.

structure_content.chapter_title: PART WON: STRETCH THE INTERNAL STEEL
structure_content.summary: This part outlines 'The Five Commandments (The Pentabarf)' of Discordianism, including the key injunction 'A Discordian is Prohibited of Believing what he reads.' It further elaborates on the philosophical distinction between 'dogma' (blind belief) and 'catma' (absolute refusal to believe in anything), positioning catma as an enabling principle for understanding and manipulating reality within the Discordian framework, ultimately asserting that 'In Chaos, there is no conflict'.

structure_content.chapter_title: PART TOO: THE VAPOR DRAGON TOOK ITS REVENGE ON THE MAZE KING
structure_content.summary: Focuses on character creation for the 'Discordian Double Agent' within the game's narrative. Players develop 'Backgrounds' (aspects of an Agent's past, analogous to skills or aptitudes), which can include 'High Weirdness' as a free, mutable background representing Eris's direct influence. Agents must also choose a 'Conspiracy' to infiltrate, each associated with a unique 'Dogma' power, which they learn to wield while balancing it against their intrinsic 'Catma'.

structure_content.chapter_title: PART FOR: MAKE FIVES, SURRENDER THE SUDDEN
structure_content.summary: Details the core 'taking risks' game mechanic, 'Making Fives.' Players roll six-sided dice and combine face values (addition/subtraction) to create numbers divisible by five, counting these as 'successes' against a 'Risk Difficulty'. This section also covers 'Advantage Dice' (bonuses for good roleplaying or circumstantial advantages), 'Contested Risks' (player-vs-player rolls), and the simplified 'Combat' system, including rules for 'Initiative', 'Actions & Rounds', 'Attack & Defend', 'Wounds', and 'Healing', all framed within a narrative-first approach.

structure_content.chapter_title: PART V: VOX COOKIES THWART PAIN AND REVENGE
structure_content.summary: This is the most crucial section for the practical operative system. It explains 'Catma' as the power of disbelief, allowing Agents to bend reality ('Weird events') and double dice rolls by spending Catma points. 'Dogma' is presented as the power derived from an Agent's infiltrated Conspiracy, granting specific abilities (e.g., Bavarian Illuminati's Power to force behaviors, Hashashin's Will for resilience, Rosicrucian's Alchemy to transform elements, Knights Templar's Fraternitas to lend strength, Alien's Fear to paralyze, Priests of the Secret Sign's Madness to infect targets). The inherent risk of using Dogma, which can erode Catma and potentially transform an Agent into a 'Triple Agent' (working against Discordianism), is also detailed.

structure_content.chapter_title: PART ATE: SPARSE SMOKE IN THE DIAMOND SUMMONS THE NETHER ARMADA
structure_content.summary: A section for the Game Master, offering guidance on 'Running Discordia!' and 'Generating Discordian Adventures.' It advocates for using William Burroughs' 'cut-up method' with random words to create adventure hooks and scenarios, directly applying the 'everything is true' principle. Sample adventure premises are provided, demonstrating how seemingly disparate elements can be synthesized into cohesive (or hilariously incoherent) narratives, reinforcing the game's core philosophy of chaos as a creative force.

A concluding section featuring a collection of quotes from various figures (Akhenaten, Charles Fort, Emperor Norton, Robert Anton Wilson, Nietzsche, etc.) that resonate with or directly relate to Discordian philosophical tenets concerning reality, order, chaos, and perception. These serve to reinforce the conceptual underpinnings of the game and its esoteric influences.

key_concepts.definition: A post-modern philosophical and religious movement centered on Eris, the Greek Goddess of Chaos, emphasizing chaos as the fundamental principle of the universe and rejecting artificial order and dogma. It promotes epistemological anarchy, where all truths (and non-truths) are equally valid.

Defined as 'the absolute refusal to believe in anything,' Catma is the operative force representing a Discordian Agent's ability to bend or transcend the 'laws of reality'. Spending a Catma point enables 'Weird events' (supernatural or improbable occurrences) and doubles the number of dice rolled for the subsequent risk. It is intimately linked to 'High Weirdness'.

Defined as 'a definite authoritative tenet' or 'a point of view or tenet put forth as authoritative without adequate grounds,' Dogma is the operative power derived from an Agent's infiltrated Conspiracy. Each Conspiracy possesses a specific Dogma (e.g., Power, Will, Alchemy, Fraternitas, Fear, Madness) which grants unique abilities. Using Dogma carries the risk of decreasing Catma, potentially leading to 'Triple Agent' status.

The player character in the game, who outwardly serves an Illuminati-like conspiracy (adopting its Dogma) while inwardly remaining devoted to Eris and the principles of Chaos (maintaining Catma). Their role is to subvert order from within.

A unique Background possessed by all Discordian Double Agents, starting at Rank 2. It represents Eris's direct influence and allows for the occurrence of bizarre events. Invoking High Weirdness costs a Catma point, doubles dice, and if successful, triggers a random 'weird event' while decreasing the High Weirdness rank.

The core dice mechanic for resolving 'Risks' and 'Combat'. Players roll six-sided dice and combine the face values through addition or subtraction to create numbers divisible by five. Each successful multiple of five counts as a 'success' against a target 'Difficulty'.

A foundational myth in Discordianism, where Eris, the goddess of chaos, was intentionally excluded from a party, leading her to instigate discord by introducing the Golden Apple 'For the Fairest', ultimately causing the Trojan War. This act serves as a model for Discordian intervention against imposed order.

The ultimate failure state for a Discordian Double Agent. If an Agent's Catma reaches zero due to excessive Dogma use, they become a Triple Agent, fully indoctrinated by their infiltrated Conspiracy and working actively against the Discordian movement.

Alchemical weapons, such as pistols, created by Rosicrucian Agents by transforming 'base fire into pure fire'. These weapons provide a significant combat advantage, granting 6 'Advantage Dice' to the user.

practical_system.description: The practical system of 'Discordia!' is a tabletop role-playing game designed to enact Discordian and Chaos Magical principles through character interaction and dice mechanics. Players embody 'Discordian Double Agents' who operate by balancing 'Catma' (the power of absolute non-belief, allowing for reality bending and dice bonuses) against 'Dogma' (specific powers derived from infiltrated Illuminati-like conspiracies). The core mechanic, 'Making Fives', uses d6s to generate successes, representing the agent's ability to impose their will or desired reality upon chaotic circumstances. The system emphasizes narrative flexibility, player creativity, and the philosophical implications of belief and disbelief as operative forces.
tools: Six-sided dice (d6s): The primary implement for resolving 'Risks', 'Combat', and 'Initiative' through the 'Making Fives' mechanic.
Catma Points: A conceptual resource representing an Agent's reservoir of non-belief, spent to initiate 'Weird events' and gain dice bonuses. Gained through increasing chaos and befuddling the GM.

Dogma Points: A conceptual resource representing an Agent's access to the specific powers of their chosen Conspiracy, spent to activate these abilities. Using Dogma points leads to a test against Catma, risking its depletion.
Hot Dogs (bun-less): The ritualistic tool for the 'Devotive Ceremony', symbolizing defiance of dogma.

Symbolic Weapons: Objects like knives, swords, staves, cups, or coins used in Rosicrucian Alchemy rituals to facilitate elemental transformations. Orichalcum weapons (alchemical firearms) act as potent tools, providing high Advantage Dice in combat.
rituals: The Devotive Ceremony: A Friday ritual involving the joyous consumption of a hot dog without a bun, designed to 'remonstrate against the popular Paganisms of the Day' (various dietary restrictions), symbolizing liberation from arbitrary rules and dogmas.

Invoking Catma: An internal act of absolute non-belief, externally manifested by declaring a 'Weird event' (a supernatural or reality-bending occurrence) and spending a Catma point. This ritual allows the Agent to double their dice pool for the subsequent 'Risk', effectively bending reality to their will.

Activating Dogma Powers: A conscious invocation and expenditure of a Dogma point to manifest a specific power tied to the Agent's infiltrated Conspiracy (e.g., Bavarian 'Power' commands, Hashashin 'Will' for resilience, Rosicrucian 'Alchemy' for elemental transformation, Knights Templar 'Fraternitas' for shared strength, Alien 'Fear' to paralyze, Priests of the Secret Sign 'Madness' to infect minds). Each invocation risks the Agent's Catma.

Rosicrucian Alchemy: A ceremonial act requiring 1-2 actions and often a 'symbolic weapon' (knife, sword, staff, cup, coin) to transmute elements (e.g., earth to water, base material to pure material). This is a focused application of Dogma for material and energetic manipulation.

relevant_quotes.text: Chaos is the Natural Condition of Reality. Those who see order see their own dogma.

critical_analysis.relevance: 'Discordia!' serves as a compelling practical manual for Chaos Magic practitioners and those interested in the operative applications of belief systems. It directly translates the core Discordian philosophy of epistemological anarchy ('Everything is true') into game mechanics, offering a structured yet flexible framework for reality manipulation. The interplay between 'Catma' (radical disbelief, analogous to gnosis or belief suspension in Chaos Magic) and 'Dogma' (structured belief, analogous to magical paradigms or godforms) provides a tangible system for understanding how belief can be wielded and how adherence to a single belief system can limit one's magical potential. The 'cut-up method' for adventure generation further aligns with Chaos Magic's emphasis on randomness, syncretism, and the generation of meaningful patterns from arbitrary inputs. It functions as an experiential thought-experiment on the nature of reality, belief, and magical agency.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This work is primarily targeted at practitioners of Chaos Magic, Discordians, and those within the wider Western Esoteric and Occult traditions who explore belief as a magical tool. It is also highly relevant for tabletop role-playing game enthusiasts who appreciate narrative-driven, philosophical, or improvisational systems, particularly those interested in games that blur the lines between simulation, philosophical discourse, and practical magical/psychological experimentation.
